context.purpose: Assess clonogenic potential of cells after FSS exposure to determine long-term viability.
context.prior_step: 5.3 Washing cells with PBS
context.next_step: 5.5 Comparing viability of sheared and static samples

corrected_text: Clonogenic assay 1. Take 100uL of the static sample, and add 900uL of growth medium to make a 1:10 dilution. 2. Take 100 µL of the 1:10 diluted sample, and add 900 µL of growth medium to make a final 1:100 dilution. 3. Add 100uL of the 1:100 dilution sample into each of 3 wells of a 6-well dish containing 2 mL of growth medium. 4. Repeat steps 3.4.1-3.4.3 with samples that have been subjected to 10 pulses of FSS. 5. Let the cells grow for 7-10 days without changing the medium, and check for colony formation. Once colonies of 250 cells have formed, aspirate the growth medium, rinse each well with 1 m L of PBS, aspirate the PBS, and fix for 5 min using 1m L of ice-cold 70% ethanol (EtOH). Importantly, fix both sheared and static samples at the same time 6. After fixing the samples, aspirate the EtOH, and add 1 to 2m L of crystal violet solution 0.1% crystal violet in 90% H2O, 10% EtOH) for 5:m i n . 7. Rinse with an excess of water, and let the plate dry 8. Count the colonies (clusters of 250 cells) for both the static and sheared samples. Compare the ratio of the average number of colonies from the sheared sample to the average number of colonies from the static sample to determine viability.

Use gauze to protect the surrounding tissues to avoid the weighing paper from touching the surrounding kidney and intestine.

context.purpose: Monitor post-operative recovery and provide analgesia to ensure the well-being of the animals.

corrected_text: Monitor the mice twice a day to assess for redness, swelling, and pain or abdominal infection. Provide meloxicam (0.5 mg/kg, SC) to all mice about 1 h before and 24h after the RDN procedure.

You don't want to suck up all of the embryos in one go, and your don't want the tip so small that it takes 5 minutes to suck up the cells. Aim for somewhere in between. Examine the embryos with transmitted light and use a mouth suction tube attached to the pipet to remove the contents of the embryo. context.purpose: Maintaining the mouse's body temperature during anesthesia to prevent hypothermia.
context.prior_step: 2.1 Anesthetize a mouse with pentobarbital sodium
context.next_step: 2.3 Removal of hair from the ventral side

corrected_text: Anesthesia compromises temperature regulation, so keep the mouse warm immediately after the first injection of pentobarbital. Using a metal carrier (ventilated aluminum basket) on top of a heating plate (calibrated to 37°C_iota works well to keep the temperature of the mouse stable. Alternatively, use a heat lamp, taking care to position it at an appropriate distance from the mouse. Monitor the mouse every 5-10 min until the appropriate level of anesthesia is achieved (lack of withdrawal to toe or tail pinch). A supplementary dose may be required after 15-20 min. It is best to proceed slowly and with caution to avoid overdose, especially with obese, aged, or animals otherwise stressed.

Tip: using the trituration pipette, move the adventitia away from the endothelial tube as soon as possible to keep it from entangling the tube. Note: Using the trituration pipette, the isolated endothelial tube can be aspirated and transferred to a separate chamber.

To plate using serial dilution, transfer each fly homogenate to the first row of a 96 well plate. 2. Fill each well of the remaining rows with 90ul of PBS. 3. Using a multichannel pipette, take 10ul from the first row containing fly homogenate and dispense into the second row. 4. Pipette up and down at least 10 times to thoroughly mix, and then take 10ul and transfer to the third row. Repeat this procedure using the remaining rows. 5. corrected_text: Plate the homogenate on an LB agar plate, either using a spiral plater or a serial dilution. 1. To plate using serial dilution, transfer each fly homogenate to the first row of a 96 well plate. 2. Fill each well of the remaining rows with 90ul of PBS. 3. Using a multichannel pipette, take 10ul from the first row containing fly homogenate and dispense into the second row. 4. Pipette up and down at least 10 times to thoroughly mix, and then take 10ul and transfer to the third row. Repeat this procedure using the remaining rows. 5. Starting from the bottom row (most dilute bacteria suspension), use the multichannel pipette to take 10ul from each well and deposit on an LB plate, taking care that the samples are dispensed as discrete spots that do not touch each other. Repeat until all wells have been sampled from each row, dispensing them in descending order of dilution on the LB plate. 6. Leave the plate at RT until the spots have completely soaked into the LB plate.
error_description: Starting the plating process from the top row (most concentrated) instead of the bottom row (most dilute) could lead to cross-contamination and inaccurate bacterial load quantification.

Place the cuvette in a cuvette holder so that worms are initially near the top of the cuvette. Using the mirrors, steer the laser beam through the center of the cuvette. context.purpose: To transfer nematodes to a quartz cuvette for laser diffraction analysis.
context.prior_step: Washing of nematodes to remove adhering bacteria.
context.next_step: Optical setup for video analysis.

corrected_text: Transfer nematodes in water or buffer to a quartz cuvette using a micropipette. It is important to work with a small number, about 5-10 nematodes in total at one time or even fewer so that one nematode at a time is likely to be illuminated by the laser. If the number of nematodes on the culture plates is too large, dilute the worms in water or buffer until a desired density is reached. It is also possible to pick individual nematodes to a drop of water or buffer on a fresh agar plate to wash them and transfer individual worms to the cuvette. In our study, we used 1 mm, 2 mm and 5:mm cuvette sizes to examine the effects of physical constraints on swimming behavior.

context.purpose: To set up the optical system for laser diffraction analysis of nematode locomotion.
context.prior_step: Transfer of nematodes to a quartz cuvette.
context.next_step: Mixing nematodes into the water column.

corrected_text: Perform setup as shown in Figure 1 using a 543n m (green) Helium-Neon (HeNe) laser, two front-surface aluminum mirrors, a cuvette holder, a projection screen, and a high-speed camera (Casio High Speed Exilim) capable of filming at 240 fps. The two mirrors are used to steer the laser beam through the cuvette. Different sizes of cuvettes can be used depending on the nature of the study. As an example, we used cuvettes that are 5:mm thick to show the effects of spatial constraints on swimming frequencies. The laser beam must fulfill the requirements for oversampling; i.e., the organism should obstruct no more than one third of the laser beam. For C. elegans, the laser beam should be about 2m m in diameter when it interacts with a nematode. The laser beam should not be larger than 5:m m in diameter since the diffraction pattern will be difficult to locate. The distance from the diffracting organism to the screen should be much larger than the organism itself.

context.purpose: To reduce scattering from the transmitted laser beam, preventing camera saturation.
context.prior_step: Steering the laser beam through the cuvette.
context.next_step: Drawing a line on the projection screen for scale.

corrected_text: On the projection screen, color the spot corresponding to the transmitted laser beam black to reduce scattering as the transmitted beam meets the projection screen (Figure 2). Alternatively put an opening in the projection screen to allow the transmitted beam to pass through the screen. Eliminating or reducing scattering from the transmitted beam will keep the CCD array of the camera from saturating due to the transmitted beam.
